head.title: Lucent and MapInfo to Sell Location-Based Web Services

identified-content.classifier: Top/Classifieds/Job Market/Job Categories/Technology, Telecommunications and Internet

hedline.hl1: Lucent and MapInfo to Sell Location-Based Web Services

abstract.p: Lucent Technologies and MapInfo Corp plan to jointly develop location-based services for wireless Internet industry; will package services and sell them to network carriers, not individual consumers; will make services available for mobile phones and hand-held devices (M)

block.p: Responding to a growing sector of the wireless Internet industry, Lucent Technologies and the MapInfo Corporation are expected to announce today that they will jointly develop location-based services for mobile communications devices.

Location-based services are one of the fastest-growing and most heavily promoted parts of the wireless Internet industry. According to one example of technology that companies like MapInfo, Lucent and others are developing, a cell-phone user would be alerted when near a restaurant serving a cuisine he or she likes and would be provided the chance to view the menu and make reservations.

Responding to a growing sector of the wireless Internet industry, Lucent Technologies and the MapInfo Corporation are expected to announce today that they will jointly develop location-based services for mobile communications devices.

Location-based services are one of the fastest-growing and most heavily promoted parts of the wireless Internet industry. According to one example of technology that companies like MapInfo, Lucent and others are developing, a cell-phone user would be alerted when near a restaurant serving a cuisine he or she likes and would be provided the chance to view the menu and make reservations.
MapInfo, based in Troy, N.Y., develops software to let businesses use geography to analyze their markets. Lucent, based in Murray Hill, N.J., is a leading maker of communications equipment.

While concerns over individual privacy and the technical feasibility of location-based applications have been raised, some companies are betting that the advertising and revenue potential for wireless communications carriers will be substantial. Lucent and MapInfo plan to package their services and sell them to network carriers instead of to individual consumers.
''We'll provide the picks and shovels to make the pinpointing of a consumer globally an attractive option,'' Mark Cattini, president of MapInfo, said in a telephone interview.

MapInfo and Lucent plan to base their services on existing technical formats that are more common in Europe than the United States -- like the wireless application protocol, or WAP, and the global standard for mobile communications, or G.S.M. The companies plan to make their services available for mobile phones and Palm hand-held devices.

''There's been concern over the fortune spent on wireless licenses in Europe, so we're presenting carriers there with a way to recoup some of their costs,'' said Stacey J. Gelman, Lucent's vice president for mobile Internet operations.

Eventually, the companies plan to upgrade their services to be made compatible with the next generation of wireless formats expected to appear over the next several years. The next generation of formats may allow for much faster wireless Internet access, but the slow pace of the rollout has been a stumbling block for companies seeking to develop wireless Internet applications.
